GERD can cause esophagitis, which is inflammation and irritation of the esophagus. The biopsy is most likely to show simple columnar epithelium, which is the normal tissue lining of the lower esophagus and stomach. Sublingual nitroglycerin is expected to relieve chest discomfort in patients with angina or ischemic heart disease, but worsen it in patients with esophageal spasm, which is more commonly associated with GERD.
